node.title: Netflix buys a visual effects company in a move to support its global ambitions.
node.alt: Scanline VFX has worked with Netflix on  the third season of “Stranger Things,” above, and “Cowboy Bebop.”
node.description: Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but the company, Scanline VFX, will continue to operate independently.
node.content: ["In an effort to ramp up its visual effects capabilities around the world, Netflix announced Monday that it was acquiring Scanline VFX, a German company that is advancing efforts in virtual production.", "Scanline has worked with the streaming service on \u201cCowboy Bebop,\u201d the third season of \u201cStranger Things\u201d and upcoming projects like \u201cThe Gray Man\u201d with Ryan Gosling and Chris Evans, \u201cThe Adam Project\u201d featuring Ryan Reynolds and Adam McKay\u2019s \u201cDon\u2019t Look Up.\u201d", "Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but Scanline will continue to operate independently and will still work on projects outside Netflix. It has previously done work on TV shows like \u201cGame of Thrones\u201d and movies like \u201cGodzilla vs King Kong.\u201d The deal is expected to close in the first quarter of 2022.", "Scanline VFX was founded in 1989 by Stephan Trojansky and has more than 1,000 employees with offices in seven locations around the world, including South Korea, Canada, England and the United States.", "Netflix \u201cwill invest in Scanline\u2019s pipeline, infrastructure and work force and continue to support the pioneering work that Scanline\u2019s Eyeline Studios is doing in virtual production to push the boundaries of what is visibly possible,\u201d Amy Reinhard, Netflix\u2019s vice president of studio operations, wrote in a blog post.", "Virtual production, which relies on walls of LED screens to show a virtual location is becoming more of a mainstay for studios. Disney\u2019s \u201cThe Mandalorian\u201d is perhaps the most prominent example. The imagery on the screen can match the camera\u2019s viewpoint in real time and provide lighting for the physical set.", "Netflix has become more acquisitive in recent months. It announced in September that it would spend more than $700 million to purchase the Roald Dahl Story Company. It also disclosed that month that it intended to purchase its first game studio \u2014 Night School Studio \u2014 to further its efforts around video games."]
